Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figure pottery column-krater; interior: glazed black; exterior: above, hind part of siren to right (in added white, outlined in black, with added red on wing); at left, trace of undetermined black-figure decoration; below, two dilute lines; in lower frieze rump and tail of goat to left and head, neck, chest and right wing of swan, also to left; cruciform rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The piece has an unusual ground, as if a red slip had been applied and them scraped off. It is more fully discussed by A. Johnston, 'Another two-and-a-half Corinthian dipinti', in Egraphsen kai Epoiesen (Essays on Greek pottery and iconography in honour of Professor Michalis Tiverios), Thessaloniki 2014, 122, with fig. 4.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B103.18)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (no.1470A)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p.111, no. A180)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p.221, no. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.059) (Phase 1)
